I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Global Environment 
Facility (GEF), both to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Shaanxi Weinan Luyang 
Integrated  Saline  Land  Management  Project. 1  The  report  also  describes  proposed 
administration of technical assistance (TA) to be provided by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund2 under 
the Water Financing Partnership Facility for the Management and Protection of Wetlands in 
Weinan City in Shaanxi Province, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under 
the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.3 
 
2.  The project is located in Luyanghu, a low-lying waterlogged area 35 kilometers (km) 
north  of  Weinan  city,  Shaanxi  province.  The  project  will  support  the  Weinan  municipal 
government  (WMG)  in  reducing  flood  risk,  soil  salinity,  and  waterlogging  for  an  economic 
development zone and agricultural lands in the Luyanghu area, which will directly benefit rural 
communities in the area. The project will also support the WMG in finalizing and implementing a 
management plan for the Luyanghu National Wetland Park (LNWP), in close cooperation with 
the  local  communities,  which  will  ensure  wetland  conservation  while  creating  new 
nonagricultural livelihood opportunities through tourism and other activities.4  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Government  development  strategy.  In  2009,  the  State  Council  approved  the 
establishment of the Guanzhong–Tianshui Economic Zone (GTEZ), one of three economic 
development zones defined in the Eleventh Five-Year Plan for the western region.5  The GTEZ 
will cover 79,800 square kilometers (km2) in selected cities of Shaanxi and Gansu provinces 
with construction planned from 2009 to 2020.6 By 2020 the gross domestic product output of the 
GTEZ is expected to reach one-third of the western region. The municipal government of 
Weinan city, which is located in the east of Guanzhong Plain and part of the GTEZ, designated 
the Luyanghu area as one of the development areas in the GTEZ. The WMG has a long-term 
development  plan  (2007–2025)  for  the  Luyanghu  area  to  attract  high-technology  industrial 
investment,  promote  tourism,  and  create  job  opportunities.  In  December  2007,  the  WMG 
established the Weinan Luyanghu Modern Industry Development Zone Management Committee 
(WLMIDZMC)  to  coordinate  development  efforts,  and  the  Weinan  Luyang  Construction 
Development Company to be responsible for infrastructure improvement. 
 
4.  Luyanghu  comprises  a  total  watershed  of  1,123  km2  across  Fuping  and  Pucheng 
counties.  It  is  a  national  poverty  area.  In  2012,  the  population  of  the  project  area  is 
approximately 113,000, mostly rural villagers; approximately 30% of rural households live below 
                                                
1  The original title was ―Shaanxi Weinan Luyang Integrated Saline and Alkaline Land Management Project.‖ 
2  Contributors: the governments of Australia, Austria, Norway, Spain, and Switzerland. 
3  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
4  ADB provided project preparatory technical assistance. ADB. 2010.Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic 
of China for Preparing the Shaanxi Weinan Luyang Integrated Saline and Alkaline Land Management Project. 
Manila. 
5  The policy covers (i) six provinces: Gansu, Guizhou, Qinghai, Shaanxi, Sichuan, and Yunnan; (ii) five autonomous 
regions: Guangxi, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Xizang (also known as Tibet Autonomous Region), and Xinjiang; and 
(iii) one municipality: Chongqing. In 2009, this region comprised 71.4% of mainland People’s Republic of China’s 
area, but only 28.8% of its population and 19.9% of its total economic output.  
6  ADB also finances the Gansu Tianshui Urban Infrastructure Development Project, which aims to enable Tianshui 
city to meet urbanization pressures and maximize Guangzhong–Tianshui Economic Zone-related benefits.

2 
the Weinan municipal poverty line of CNY2,500. Their 2010 average per capita income was only 
CNY4,372, one-third lower than the Shaanxi provincial average and roughly a quarter of the 
average annual income of urban residents in the same municipality. Agricultural productivity is 
low because of poor soil conditions and drainage problems. Local residents grow limited wheat 
and corn crops, with production only half of that in other areas of Weinan city. A small but active 
salt-harvesting and processing industry continues and needs to be preserved. 
 
5.  Land management. The decades-long poor environmental conditions of the Luyanghu 
area  are  mainly  due  to  long-term  problems  of  saline  soil,  high  groundwater  tables,  poor 
drainage systems, and subsequent flooding problems. The groundwater table is approximately 
0–3 meters below the surface. The salt and mineral content of groundwater and soil is now very 
high in certain areas, significantly reducing agricultural productivity. In 1974, to reduce the salt 
content and improve agricultural productivity, the government established the Luoxi desalination 
drainage system, which comprises one main desalination drainage channel, four subcanals, and 
branch and secondary branch drainage channels. The system serves an area of approximately 
212 km2. Due to insufficient investment, the original design of the desalination system was of 
poor quality, and lack of maintenance made the system ineffective to reduce soil salinity.  
 
6.  The WMG envisages a balanced approach to promoting and protecting the economic 
development zone (covering approximately 15 km2), while improving the natural environment 
and supporting rural livelihoods in the surrounding agricultural lands of approximately 186 km2. 
Specific interventions needed to ensure sustained economic growth include (i) rehabilitation of 
the Luoxi desalination drainage system to remove salts from the soil, (ii) improvement of flood 
storage capacity of Luyanghu area to reduce flood risks to local residents and the development 
zone,  and  (iii)  rehabilitation  and  conservation  of  the  remaining  wetland  environment.  The 
Shaanxi provincial government (SPG) initiated establishment of the LNWP and prepared a draft 
master plan, but no further activities have been carried out.  
 
7.  Consistency with country partnership strategy. The project supports ADB's country 
partnership  strategy  (CPS)  for  the  PRC,7 which  is  based  on  the  pillars  of  Strategy  2020: 
inclusive growth, environmentally sustainable growth, and regional cooperation and integration. 
Natural resources and agriculture is a CPS priority sector. ADB provides lending and technical 
assistance to contribute to sound land, water, and natural resources management that also 
support rural livelihood improvement. In particular, ADB promotes innovative and demonstration 
projects where ADB can play a catalytic role in addressing poverty, rising income inequality, and 
widening regional disparities. The project will support priorities of the PRC's Twelfth Five-Year 
Plan, 2011–2015, particularly efforts to move to a greener and more inclusive development path.  
 
8.  The project complements ongoing support to Shaanxi province, including the Shaanxi 
Qinling Biodiversity Conservation and Demonstration Project, and the Forestry and Ecological 
Restoration Project in Three Northwest Provinces.8 These projects demonstrate the important 
role that ADB plays to introduce innovative and good practices to strengthen sustainable land 
management and biodiversity conservation. ADB also served as the lead GEF agency for the 
PRC–GEF  Partnership  on  Land  Degradation  in  Dryland  Ecosystems,  which  ensured  that 
significant institutional capacity has been built in the central government, participating provinces, 
and autonomous regions, including Shaanxi province. Provincial legal and policy frameworks 
                                                
7  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2011–2015. Manila. 
8  ADB. 2009. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and 
Administration of Grant to the People’s Republic of China for the Shaanxi Qinling Biodiversity Conservation and 
Demonstration Project. Manila; and ADB. 2011. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of 
Directors: Proposed Loan and Administration of Grant to the People’s Republic of China for the Forestry and 
Ecological Restoration Project in Three Northwest Provinces. Manila.

3 
have  been  developed,  provincial  integrated  ecosystem  management  strategies  and  best 
practices  prepared,  and  an  integrated  ecosystem  approach  applied  to  address  land 
degradation.  The  current  focus  of  the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China 
(government) is to scale up the activities through supportive investment projects.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact will be sustained and inclusive economic growth in Weinan municipality. The 
outcome will be improved natural environment and rural livelihood in Luyanghu area.  
 
C.  Outputs 
 
10.  Output  1:  Saline  soils  rehabilitated.  Output  1  will  reduce  soil  salinity  over 
approximately 212 km2 and increase productivity and climate resilience of approximately 186 
km2 of agricultural land. It has two components: (i) rehabilitation of Luoxi drainage system, and 
(ii)  support for  improving resilience  to  climate change  of  agro-ecosystems.  Under the first 
component, activities include (i) dredging and rehabilitating approximately 46.9 km of the main 
desalination  drainage  channels;  (ii)  dredging  approximately  90.3  km  of  the  branch  and 
secondary  branch  drainage  channels;  (iii) rehabilitating  approximately  450  small  structures, 
including approximately 153 bridges, 69 culverts, 54 aqueducts, and 174 flow confluences; (iv) 
constructing and rehabilitating approximately 35.6 km of rural roads; (v) testing at least 10 
innovative and replicable best practices for rehabilitating saline soil approximately over 100 
hectares (ha), including discussions with farmers on implementation arrangements and support 
for  implementation  over  the  larger  project  area;  and  (vi)  providing  training  on  saline  land 
management to support expansion to a larger area. Under the second component, support will 
be provided to (i) reduce the vulnerability of local communities to climate change through 
enhanced provision of regulating ecosystem services, such as water and temperature regulation 
and soil retention, and (ii) local farmers to improve crop productivity in the approximately 186 
km2  of  agricultural  areas  where  drainage  will  be  improved.  Activities  to  support  improved 
resilience to climate change include (i) testing of at least two innovative and replicable best 
practices for the establishment of shelter belts (covering approximately 2 ha); (ii) construction of 
approximately 130 ha of greenbelts; and (iii) support for farmers to market their products and 
increase alternative income generating livelihood. Suitable activities—particularly items (v) and 
(vi) under the first component, and item (iii) under the second component—will also target 
households headed by women to ensure that they equally benefit from the project.  
 
11.  Output 2: Flood risk management implemented. Output 2 will improve flood storage 
capacity of Luyanghu area to reduce flood risks to local residents. It includes (i) construction of 
Tianlu lake (approximately 130 ha), connecting Tianjiao lake in the west, a middle main channel, 
and a central main channel; and (ii) construction of approximately 18.6 km of dike with road 
around Tianlu lake. Combined with Tianjiao lake, the project will provide flood storage capacity 
of 5.4 million cubic meters to protect against flood events, with maximum capacity of 12.6 million 
cubic meters to protect against a 50-year flood event. The integrated and innovative approach 
combining flood risk management with drainage system rehabilitation and wetlands ecosystem 
conservation will contribute to reduced flood risk for the Luyanghu area.  
 
12.  Output  3:  Wetland  ecosystem  conservation  established.  Output  3  has  two 
components: (i) support for LNWP development; and (ii) promotion of tourism, livelihood, and 
employment  opportunities  for  local  communities.  The  wetlands  conservation  will  reverse 
ecosystem degradation caused by agricultural encroachment and other pressures associated 
with the increasing population within the project area. The first component will (i) rehabilitate 
approximately 860 ha of degraded wetlands; (ii) prepare and support implementation of the

4 
LNWP master plan for approximately 1,070 ha; (iii) establish a wetland management training 
facility; (iv) test at least two innovative and replicable best practices in wetland rehabilitation 
(covering  approximately  10  ha);  and  (v)  train  50  officials  on  wetland  environment  and 
management. The second component will support the development of ecotourism focusing on 
the ecological values of the wetlands and the cultural heritage of salt harvesting in the area. 
Training on livelihood skills will be provided for approximately 1,000 villagers, at least 50% will 
be women, and be primarily targeted at people displaced due to land acquisition.  
 
13.  Output 4: Capacity development and project implementation support provided. 
Output  4  has  two  components:  (i)  institutional  strengthening,  and  (ii)  project  management 
support during project implementation. The first will support capacity development and training 
of WMG and WLMIDZMC staff in ADB project management procedures, technical design and 
implementation,  and  safeguard  supervision  and  monitoring.  The  introduction  of  12  GEF-
financed innovative best practices for sustainable land and wetland management, together with 
the international consulting services, will significantly strengthen WMG capacity. The second 
component will provide overall project implementation support for the WMG and WLMIDZMC, 
including implementation of land acquisition and resettlement.  
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
 
14.  The project is estimated to cost $165.2 million (Table 1). ADB will finance taxes and 
duties on items financed by the ADB loan.9 The detailed cost estimates by expenditure category 
and by financier are included in the project administration manual.10

9  ADB decided to finance taxes and duties because they (i) have reasonable country thresholds, (ii) apply only to

financing of the taxes and duties is material and relevant to project success. 
10 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

5 
15.  The government  has requested  a  loan  of $100  million from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace 
period  of  5  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB's  London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year 
(the interest and other charges during construction will be capitalized in the loan), and such 
other terms  and  conditions  to  be  set forth  in the  draft  loan  and  project  agreements. The 
government will make the loan proceeds available to the SPG, while the SPG will make the loan 
proceeds, as specified in the project administration manual, available to WMG on the same 
terms and conditions as are applicable to the ADB loan. WMG will make the loan proceeds 
available as grant to the WLMIDZMC under a grant agreement.  
 
16.  The financing plan is in Table 2. ADB will finance 60.5% of the total project costs.11 
Commitment charges on the ADB loan will be capitalized under the loan. The WMG will provide 
$63.2 million equivalent as counterpart funds. To assist with the project activities related to 
saline soil management and establishment of the LNWP, the GEF will provide grant cofinancing 
equivalent to $2.0 million, to be administered by ADB.

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
the  PAM.  The  WMG  project  management  office  (PMO)  established  during  the  project 
preparatory TA (footnote 4) will be strengthened and provided with an adequate number of 
senior staff who will carry out overall supervision and monitoring of the project activities. The 
PMO will be supported by a project implementation consultant and a procurement agency.

III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
18.  The TA will support the WMG in establishing wetland management measures in at least 
one site in and/or near the project area to support similar migratory waterbird habitats in the 
area. The impact will be improved management of wetlands for migratory waterbird populations 
in Shaanxi province. The outcome will be strengthened capacity of Weinan municipality to 
mitigate impacts on migratory waterbirds and their habitats in Luyanghu area. The TA will 
contribute to the implementation of output 3 and the preparation of the project’s environmental 
monitoring plan. The TA is estimated to cost $450,000, of which $350,000 equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Multi-Donor  Trust  Fund12 under  the  Water  Financing 
Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support 
in the form of remuneration and per diem of counterpart staff, miscellaneous administrative 
support, office accommodation, local transport, and other in-kind contributions. ADB will finance 
and  engage  three  consultants  to  support  the  WMG—international  (5  person-months)  and 
national (10 person-months)—in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time) using the individual consultant selection method. The TA 
will be implemented from 1 July 2013 to 31 December 2014. The TA proceeds will be disbursed 
in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). The TA is described in detail in the PAM. Equipment purchased under the TA 
will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from 
time to time) and transferred to the WMG upon TA completion. 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
19.  Due diligence assessed the project’s technical feasibility and sustainability. The WMG’s 
domestic feasibility study report is technically sound and provides sufficient information on the 
design  feasibility.  International  and  national  consulting  services  will  provide  the  necessary 
technical support to ensure that international best practices are integrated into the final detailed 
design, and are applied during construction and implementation. The design to rehabilitate the 
drainage system is consistent with the original layout of the 1974 system, but will correct design 
features that rendered the current system ineffective: the current gradients of the main channels 
are too low and no secondary branch channels or field ditches were provided. The flood control 
infrastructure is designed to protect against a 10-year flood event over 18,600 ha, and a 50-year 
flood event over 1,500 ha of the industrial and commercial development zone. The wetland 
                                                
12  Contributors: the governments of Australia, Austria, Norway, Spain, and Switzerland.

7 
ecological conservation activities are based on the WMG’s 2012 draft wetland master plan. GEF 
will provide international and national consulting services to start implementation and strengthen 
the master plan. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
20.  The economic analysis indicates that the project is economically viable, with an overall 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  15.2%  and  an  economic  net  present  value  of 
CNY233.5 million.  The  rates  of  return  for  individual  outputs  are  14.3%  for  saline  soil 
rehabilitation,  15.6%  for  flood  risk  management,  and  14.2%  for  wetland  ecosystem 
conservation.  Sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  the  project  is  generally  robust  to  potential 
variations  in  costs  and  benefits.  The  project  remains  economically  viable  even  with  a 
combination of a benefit decline of 10.0% and a capital cost increase of 10.0%. In addition, the 
actual economic benefits are likely larger than estimated as some significant types of benefits 
are not quantifiable due to data limitation. Given that the outputs do not generate revenue, 
financial analysis focuses on the project’s fiscal impact on governments. The annual counterpart 
financing requirement during project implementation, as a ratio of the projected annual revenues 
of the WMG, ranges from 0.1% to 2.1%. Estimated annual loan repayment falls within the range 
of 0.02% to 0.2%. The annual operation and maintenance cost, as a ratio of the projected 
revenue of WLMIDZMC, ranges from 1.8% to 3.0% during the first 5 years and then falls below 
1.0%. The low ratios indicate acceptable fiscal risk. Assessments of the financial management 
and institutional capacity of the WMG and WLMIDZMC, and the PMO concluded that the 
financial  management  systems  satisfy  ADB  requirements  and  identified  areas  that  need 
strengthening. Capacity development measures are recommended, for the PMO in particular, to 
strengthen capacity to implement the project in compliance with ADB policies and operational 
and procedural requirements. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
21.  The financial management assessment shows that, with capacity strengthening, the 
financial management arrangements  of  the WMG  finance  bureau  and WLMIDZMC  will  be 
sufficient for project implementation in terms of financial and management accounting, reporting, 
auditing, internal controls, and disbursement and cash flow management. The procurement 
capacity  assessment  indicates  that  the  WMG  and  WLMIDZMC  (i)  have  established 
arrangements for handling procurement, including bid document preparation, tender invitation, 
bid evaluation, contract award, construction supervision, and contract performance monitoring; 
and (ii) will engage a professional procurement agency experienced in managing procurement 
processes financed by international development institutions. Given the lack of experience in 
managing ADB-financed projects and familiarity with ADB policies, guidelines, and procedural 
requirements, ADB will provide assistance and training in project management for WMG and 
WLMIDZMC staff. 
 
22.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  WMG.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
23.  Employment,  livelihood,  and  poverty.  The  project  area  has  a  population  of 
approximately 113,000 who will benefit from improved livelihood from employment, capacity 
development, increased agricultural yield and productivity, and participation. The reduction in 
soil salinity is expected to increase overall rural production value by up to CNY300 million over

8 
the project life, and the improvement of flood protection to reduce losses due to floods on 
farmland by around CNY480 million. The project will directly improve agricultural productivity 
and  yields  through  improved  cropping,  farmer  field  schools,  capacity  development,  good 
agricultural practices and other measures. Capacity development on the use of the improved 
saline soils and sustainable livelihood financed under the GEF grant will help ensure increased 
agricultural productivity from the soil improved by the rehabilitated drainage system, which will 
lead  to  improved  livelihoods  and  increased  income  of  farmers  and  villagers.  Sustainable 
livelihood activities, e.g., community-based ecotourism, marketing, and improved value-chain for 
crops  such  as tree  crops,  will focus  on  capacity  development for farmers  and  other  local 
beneficiaries.  Empowerment  of  women  and  participation  of  rural  poor  and  vulnerable 
households in project design, and decision making affecting beneficiaries and local communities 
will  be  ensured  during  project  implementation  through  the  social  and  gender  action  and 
participation plan. The project will benefit poor and vulnerable households that will have more 
diverse,  nonagricultural  livelihoods,  and  improve  their  agriculture-based  livelihoods.  These 
households will benefit in particular through increased resilience to shocks such as floods. 
 
24.  The GEF grant will finance pilot activities under output 1 to test models for improved soil 
management and utilization, support expansion to the larger area, and establish farmer field 
schools to spread the pilots. Under output 3, wetland ecosystem restoration, the GEF grant will 
finance testing of options for improved saltpan management, and alternative livelihoods in 
wetlands,  including  community-based  ecotourism  and  alternative  livelihoods  for  local 
communities. Under the TA for Mainstreaming Environment for Poverty Reduction, ADB is 
cooperating with local civil society organizations to improve livelihoods by designing and piloting 
capacity  development  measures  to  improve  employment  prospects  based  on  participatory 
assessment of poor households.13  
 
25.  Gender.  Gender  design  elements  to  ensure  the  project  achieves  effective  gender 
mainstreaming  are  included  in  the  project  design  and  will  be  implemented  by  the  project 
accordingly. The social and gender action and participation plan contains features to ensure 
project benefits are accrued by women at least as equally as by men. This will be achieved by 
ensuring (i) their participation in project activities and decision making processes relevant to 
their communities; (ii) they benefit from employment opportunities created under the project; (iii) 
they can and will participate in capacity development measures under the project, in particular 
those  related  to  alternative  livelihood;  and  (iv)  they  are  included  in  capacity  development 
measures for project management. Plan implementation will be monitored through the collection 
of sex-disaggregated data on project activities. Selected activities under outputs 1 and 3 will 
ensure households headed by women benefit at least equally from employment and training 
opportunities as other households. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
26.  Environment  (category  A).  The  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA)  report, 
including an environmental management plan (EMP) follows ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009). The EIA is consistent with the domestic EIA, approved on 24 July 2012 by the Shaanxi 
environment protection department. Consultations involved key stakeholders, including affected 
people and local government agencies and the outcomes are integrated in the project design. 
The draft EIA was publicly disclosed on ADB’s website on 8 August 2012. The WMG, through 
the  PMO,  will  be  responsible  for  implementation  and  compliance  with  the  EMP,  including 
inspection, monitoring, reporting, and initiating corrective actions or measures. The PMO will 
                                                
13 ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Mainstreaming Environment for Poverty Reduction. Manila (TA 6422-REG).

9 
implement  a  grievance  redress  mechanism  to  handle  disputes.  A  capacity  development 
program, which includes environmental monitoring, is included in the project activities. 
 
27.  Environmental benefits will be achieved through (i) designation and management of the 
LNWP, (ii) protection of natural wetland habitats, (iii) monitoring and management of migratory 
water birds and habitats, and (iv) improved local agency capacity for wetland management. 
Adverse project impacts include (i) loss of 110 ha of habitat for some migratory water-bird 
populations due to construction of Tianlu lake; (ii) risk of eutrophication in Tianlu and Tianjiao 
lakes; and (iii) standard construction impacts, including water, soil, air, and noise pollution. 
Measures to address these include (i) develop and protect wetland habitats for migratory water 
birds in the western part of the project area,14 (ii) construct new salt-pan habitat for migratory 
water birds, (iii) incorporate additional wetland habitat in the LNWP, (iv) develop and implement 
a nutrient management plan, and (v) implement standard mitigation and monitoring measures 
during construction and operation. The EMP will be revised based on the detailed project 
design, if necessary. 
 
28.  Indigenous peoples (category C) and involuntary resettlement (category A). No 
ethnic minorities and/or indigenous communities are present in the project area (historically 
occupied by Han, the majority of the PRC population). The project will (i) permanently acquire 
approximately 172 ha (up to 115 ha currently used to harvest saltpeter, affecting 45 people and 
57 ha of agricultural land); and (ii) temporarily acquire 514 ha, mainly for soil disposal and 
construction facilities. The land acquisition will affect 1,545 people, who will lose an average of 
22% of their farmland (the majority will lose 11%–20%, 271 will lose more than 21%). No 
residential housing will be demolished.  
 
29.  To mitigate the negative impacts of economic displacements, the resettlement plan 
includes acceptable compensation standards and entitlements, external and internal monitoring, 
an implementation schedule, and budget. The grievance redress mechanism for involuntary 
resettlement will be combined with that of the EMP (para. 26). During project preparation, major 
efforts were undertaken to reduce permanent land acquisition from over 1,050 ha to the current 
number of 172 ha, to reduce the proportion of agricultural land from 50% to around 30%, and to 
improve  livelihood  restoration  measures  and  provide  replacement  land.  Temporary  land 
occupation was reduced from around 730 ha to below 480 ha, needed mainly to dispose 
temporarily of spoil from lake excavation and canal dredging. Total land acquisition costs were 
reduced significantly from around 30% to around 6% of the total project costs. The initially 
planned acquisition of significant areas of agricultural land and saltpans for the establishment of 
wetlands was averted by (i) revising the project scope and design; and (ii) excluding large areas 
initially planned for future development, and limiting land acquisition to land required strictly for 
project  use.  The  establishment  of  the  LNWP  under  management  by  the  State  Forestry 
Administration does not preclude land users from continuing their livelihood activities. According 
to the environmental assessments, the continuation of these activities will not have a negative 
impact on the wetland, and therefore no access or other livelihood restrictions are envisioned.  
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
30.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.15 The integrated benefits and impacts are 
expected to outweigh the costs. 
                                                
14 The attached TA will support the WMG in establishing these mitigation measures (para. 19). 
15 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures

Technical risks as a result of inappropriate  Adopt innovative but proven technologies, implement a nutrient 
design, lack of pollution control, capacity  management plan, and provide technical assistance during project 
limitations, and consideration of climate  design and implementation

(WLMIDZMC) 
Limited sustainability because of inadequate  WMG and WLMIDZMC assure to budget for adequate operation

maintaining the drainage and lake area. 
Loss of important habitat (salt pans) for  Construction of new salt pan habitat to maximize habitat for 
migratory waterbirds  migratory waterbird. 
Lack of local community support for  Use a participatory approach for managing the national wetland 
establishing Luyanghu National Wetland Park  park and provide training on alternative livelihoods 
The WMG’s unfamiliarity with Asian  Provide training during project implementation to WMG and 
Development Bank policies, procedures, and  WLMIDZMC staff on ADB’s guidelines and policies; ensure early 
requirements for project implementation  engagement of the procurement agency and project implementation 
consultant 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
V.  ASSURANCES 
 
31.  The government and the WMG have assured ADB that implementation of the project will 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan and project agreements.  
 
32.  The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are 
set forth in the loan and project agreements.  
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the loan of $100,000,000 to the People’s Republic of China for the Shaanxi 
Weinan  Luyang  Integrated  Saline  Land  Management  Project,  from  ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB's London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 
25  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
and project agreements presented to the Board; and  
(ii)  the administration by ADB of a grant not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 
to the People’s Republic of China for the Shaanxi Weinan Luyang Integrated 
Saline Land Management Project, to be provided by the Global Environment 
Facility. 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
23 November 2012

metadata.Keywords: china, prc, shaanxi, weinan, luyang, natural resources conservation, flood risk reduction, soil salinity reduction, wetlands conservation, desalination, luoxi drainage, wetland ecosystems, saline soil, alkaline soil, agro-ecosystems, wetlands, adb projects, rrp
metadata.Subject: This document provides the report and recommendation of the president (RRP) on (i) a proposed loan, and (ii) proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Global Environment Facility (GEF), both to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Shaanxi Weinan Luyang Integrated Saline Land Management Project.
metadata.Title: RRP: PRC: Shaanxi Weinan Luyang Integrated Saline Land Management Project
